results.title: Bitter paradise: The Sellout of East Timor
results.brief_description: Prior to Indonesian invasion and subsequent occupation, Portugese East Timor was a country far removed from external influences. Anthropologists from the west visted the country as an example of a preserved culture. Canadian tourist and photographer, Elaine Briere, visited in 1974; her photos remain as some of the only documents that attest to the peaceful existence of the country prior to invasion. Briere presents a harsh case against Western society, in particular Canada, and their complicity in allowing the military elite of the Suharto government to invade East Timor. A move that was motivated by a desire to control raw material and exploit new markets. Briere’s photographs and the testimonies provided by East Timorese who survived to tell of the atrocities that occurred are compiled as a photo documentary of the solidarity movement. More than anything, this documentary is a moving tribute to a country with a determination to maintain their independence and culture from assimilation, as well as promoting awareness of the East Timor occupation. Warning: This documentary contains scenes which may offend some viewers.

results.title: Bitter coffee = Secangkir kopi pahit
results.creator_credit: Teguh Karya, Bambang Widitomo, Njoohan Siang and Sanggar Film
results.brief_description: In one of his finest works, Teguh Karya takes an inside look at the lives of working-class ethnic Bataks in Indonesia through the film’s main character, Togar. The film opens with Togar being arrested after his wife has drowned, with the remainder of the film being told in flashbacks. The story unfolds with Togar having gone to Jakarta to pursue his ambition of being a journalist and meeting an older divorced woman at a local foodstall. He is subsequently forced to marry her when it turns out she is pregnant, only to find out later the child might not be his. He forgives his wife however and takes her, together with her children, back to his village in Jogjakarta to meet his mother, the setting of the unfortunate drowning accident. The film provides an interesting window into the lives of many such Indonesians like Togar as well as the city of Jakarta and its influence on those that live there. Cast includes Rina Hassim, Ray Sahetapy, Dewi Yull and Alex Komang. In Indonesian with English subtitles.

results.title: Black Magic (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is a film about sport and top Aboriginal sportsmen. It is predominantly an account of the creative use of sport made by the Noongar people of Western Australia’s south-west to advance their status. Through interviews with top sportsmen like the Krakouer brothers in the Victorian Football League and Archie Jones, the runner of the 1920s, the film establishes that the motivation to succeed in sport arises from a moral desire to be accepted and recognised.

results.title: Black ice
results.creator_credit: Peter Shatalow, David Springbett, Don Hopkins and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Black Ice is a short film about a group of sailing enthusiasts who have adapted the principles of the sport to winter conditions. The sight of a fragile craft whisking across a frozen lake at one hundred kilometres per hour, leaving a shower of powdered ice in its wake, is breathtaking. Iceboat racing is exciting; a sport like no other in the world. Awards: Chicago, Budapest, Cortina d’Ampezzo.

results.title: Black gold, kindred spirits
results.brief_description: The Wonthaggi State Coal Mine was arguably the most dangerous mine in Australia. Using archival footage and interviews, this film captures the spirit of Wonthaggi, her mateship and her community spirit, as elicited from the men and women who lived through the mine’s strongest days. The mine opened in 1909, and the last whistle rang in 1968, signifying the end to a place of danger and industrial turmoil. It was from this environment of danger that the workplace created a solidarity amongst workers that is both encouraging and astonishing. ‘Black gold, kindred sprit’ is a testament to this community spirit.

results.title: Black harvest
results.creator_credit: Bob Connolly, Robin Anderson and Arundel Productions
results.brief_description: Black Harvest is an extremely moving real-life drama of two ambitious men vying for power, of two cultures in conflict as a dream of wealth turns sour. In the highlands of Papua New Guinea, Joe Leahy, a mixed race Highlander and wealthy coffee plantation owner, joins forces with the Ganiga tribe to expand his empire. His greatest ally is the Ganiga tribal leader, Popina Mai, who wants to take his people into the modern world quickly. But on the eve of the coffee harvest, the work ethic and promises of wealth are abandoned as tribal warfare and tragedy erupt. This is the final part of a trilogy on the Ganiga people (“First Contact” and “Joe Leahy’s Neighbours”) made by award- winning filmmakers, Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson.

results.title: Black cloud over Bali
results.brief_description: In March 1963, Bali’s holy mountain, Gurung Agung, erupted. Over a wide area there was darkness and rain and thousands fled their homes. Molten lava poured down the mountainside killing 1,500 people; 189,000 acres of rice paddy fields were destroyed and a wide area was covered in volcanic ash. Narrated by Denis Mathews.

results.title: Black chicks talking [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Leah Purcell, Bain Stewart, BungaburBungabura Productions and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five very different Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women frankly share their life experiences and opinions. Though their backgrounds are extremely diverse, common themes of culture, family, racism and denial run through their stories, as does the ongoing personal and social legacy of past government polices of forced removal. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity. Teachers notes available through Film Australia at: http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs/default.asp?content=teachers_notes

results.title: Birth of a port
results.creator_credit: William M. Carty, Harold Dews and Cinesound Movietone
results.brief_description: Discusses the development by the Maritime Services Board of deep-water facilities in Botany Bay, New South Wales, so that it can be used as a port for large shipping.
